text.#text:
Notwithstanding
			 any other provision of law, the

header.#text:
Report on
			 military presence in Europe

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to the congressional defense committees (as defined in

) a report analyzing the necessity of
			 stationing members of the Armed Forces in Europe, including an evaluation of
			 property owned by the Federal Government in Europe that could be sold if such
			 stationing was reduced or terminated.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
			 101(a)(16) of title 10, United States Code

text.#text:
Not later than one
			 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
The report under

Benefits to the United States from having
			 the Armed Forces present in Europe that would not be achievable
			 elsewhere.

Direct military
			 threats to the United States that require such a presence and whether such
			 threats could be countered with a smaller presence.

The ability of European allies to address
			 threats without such presence.

Ways in which a
			 withdrawal or reduction of members of the Armed Forces stationed in Europe will
			 affect the sustainability of military operations abroad.

Ways in which such
			 a withdrawal or reduction will affect the ability of the United States to
			 implement a broader national security strategy.

Any formal treaty
			 obligations or bilateral agreements that require the Armed Forces of the United
			 States to be present in Europe.

Effectiveness of
			 current force levels in Europe in achieving national security
			 objectives.

Unique benefits of
			 sustaining each base location in Europe and ways in which reduction of such
			 bases would affect the ability of the United States to sustain military
			 operations abroad.
